title: What Kind of Asshole Are You?
description: Everyone's an asshole. Find out your specific flavor

traits.know_it_all: Expert on everything, master of nothing
traits.passive_aggressive: Never directly saying what you mean since forever
traits.narcissistic: Main character syndrome with a PhD in self-importance
traits.control_freak: Attempting to run everyone else's life since birth
traits.selfish_prick: It's all about you, all the time, forever
traits.emotional_manipulator: Turning feelings into weapons since childhood
traits.toxic_competitor: Turning everything into a contest you must win
traits.judgmental_critic: Finding fault in everything since you learned to talk
traits.attention_whore: Making everything about you since you could form words
traits.boundary_stomper: Personal limits are just suggestions to ignore
traits.fake_nice: Sweetness with a side of poison
traits.surprisingly_decent: Plot twist: you're not actually an asshole

questions.question: When someone disagrees with you in a group setting, what's your honest first reaction?

answers.text: Immediately explain why they're wrong using increasingly condescending language until they shut up
Smile and nod, then mentally draft ways to undermine their credibility later
Get personally offended because how dare they not recognize my obvious superiority
Turn it into a competition by bringing up my achievements and making it about success
Actually listen to their perspective and consider that I might not have all the answers

questions.question: How do you typically handle it when someone asks you for a favor you don't want to do?

answers.text: Say yes with a smile, then do a shitty job and complain about them to everyone else
Tell them no, but make sure they know how busy and important I am compared to their needs
Ignore their request completely and hope they forget, then act confused if they bring it up
Turn it around and make them feel guilty for even asking, like they're being unreasonable
Politely decline and explain my limitations without being a dick about it

questions.question: What's your honest approach to giving advice to friends with problems?

answers.text: Tell them exactly what they should do because obviously I know better about their life
Listen just long enough to make it about my own experiences and problems instead
Judge their choices harshly while pretending to be helpful and supportive
Give advice that serves my interests rather than theirs, but frame it as caring
Actually listen, ask thoughtful questions, and support them in figuring out their own solution

questions.question: How do you behave when you're in a bad mood around other people?

answers.text: Make sure everyone knows I'm upset by being passive-aggressive and making them guess what's wrong
Take it out on whoever's convenient, because if I'm miserable, everyone should be miserable
Act like everything's fine but be subtly mean and critical to make others feel shitty
Demand extra attention and sympathy while making my bad mood everyone else's problem
Take responsibility for my mood and either deal with it privately or communicate clearly

questions.question: What's your honest attitude toward people who are less successful than you?

answers.text: I feel superior and assume they just don't work as hard or aren't as smart as me
I act sympathetic to their face but secretly enjoy feeling better about myself by comparison
I offer unsolicited advice about how they could improve their life, because clearly they need my wisdom
I avoid them because their failure might be contagious and I don't want to be associated with losers
I recognize that success comes in many forms and everyone's journey is different

questions.question: How do you handle being wrong about something important?

answers.text: Find ways to prove I was actually right, or at least partially right, and definitely more right than everyone else
Blame external factors, other people, or circumstances beyond my control
Get defensive and attack the person who corrected me instead of addressing the actual issue
Acknowledge it publicly but secretly resent everyone involved and plot my comeback
Actually admit I was wrong, learn from it, and thank the person who corrected me

questions.question: What's your approach to social situations where you're not the center of attention?

answers.text: Find ways to redirect the conversation back to me and my experiences
Act bored or disinterested until someone notices and asks what's wrong
Start judging everyone else's contributions and mentally composing critiques
Try to one-up whatever story or achievement someone else is sharing
Genuinely enjoy learning about other people and supporting their moment to shine

questions.question: How do you treat service workers, waitstaff, or customer service representatives?

answers.text: I'm demanding and impatient because they're paid to serve me and should be grateful for my business
I'm polite to their face but complain loudly to my friends about how incompetent they are
I lecture them about how they could do their job better while making them uncomfortable
I use them as emotional punching bags when I'm having a bad day because they can't fight back
I treat them with basic human respect and kindness because they're people doing their job

questions.question: What's your honest approach to keeping promises and commitments to friends?

answers.text: I only keep them if it's still convenient for me when the time comes
I make elaborate excuses and act like the circumstances were beyond my control
I keep score and make sure they owe me more than I owe them
I promise things I know I can't deliver just to make them happy in the moment
I honor my commitments because my word actually means something to me

questions.question: How do you react when someone else gets recognition or success that you wanted?

answers.text: Find ways to diminish their achievement and point out why I deserved it more
Congratulate them publicly while privately seething and planning how to one-up them
Make it about how this affects me and why I'm the real victim in this situation
Immediately start bragging about my own achievements to steal their thunder
Feel disappointed but genuinely celebrate their success and learn from their approach

questions.question: When you're at a party or social gathering, what do you find yourself doing most often?

answers.text: Correcting people's facts and showing off my knowledge on every topic that comes up
Making passive-aggressive comments about the host, the food, or other guests
Making sure everyone knows about my latest achievements and how well I'm doing
Organizing everyone and telling them how to have more fun or do things better
Actually enjoying conversations and getting to know people without trying to impress them

questions.question: How do you typically respond when someone calls you out on your bad behavior?

answers.text: Explain why they're wrong and how they clearly don't understand the situation properly
Act hurt and make them feel guilty for being mean to me instead of addressing their concern
Get extremely defensive and turn it around to attack their character and flaws
Pretend to accept their criticism but then give them the silent treatment or sabotage them later
Actually consider what they're saying and apologize if they have a valid point

questions.question: What's your approach when you want something from someone but they're hesitant to give it to you?

answers.text: Explain in detail why they're being irrational and why my request makes perfect sense
Make subtle guilt trips and hints until they feel bad enough to give in
Make it all about how much I deserve it and how unfair it is that they won't help me
Keep pushing and asking until they're so tired of saying no that they eventually give in
Accept their decision and respect their right to say no without taking it personally

questions.question: How do you handle situations where you have to work in a team with people you don't particularly like?

answers.text: Take over as much as possible because obviously I'm the only one who knows how to do things right
Do the bare minimum while making sure everyone knows how much I hate being there
Act nice to their faces but undermine them behind their backs to make myself look better
Make everything into a competition to show how much better I am than everyone else
Focus on the work and try to be professional regardless of personal feelings

questions.question: What's your honest reaction when someone shares good news with you?

answers.text: Point out potential problems or why it might not work out as well as they think
Smile and congratulate them while secretly feeling jealous and resentful
Immediately try to one-up them with something better that happened to me
Make it about how their success affects me and what I get out of it
Feel genuinely happy for them and celebrate their success without making it about me

questions.question: How do you typically behave when you're running late and inconveniencing others?

answers.text: Explain in great detail why it wasn't my fault and educate them about traffic patterns or whatever caused the delay
Act like they're being unreasonable for being upset about my lateness
Make it about how stressed and overwhelmed I am, so they end up comforting me instead
Expect them to just deal with it because my time is obviously more important than theirs
Apologize sincerely and try to make up for the inconvenience I caused

questions.question: What's your approach when someone asks for your honest opinion about something important to them?

answers.text: Give them a detailed analysis of everything that's wrong and how they could do it better
Tell them what I think they want to hear, then complain about their poor choices to other people
Use it as an opportunity to talk about my own similar experiences and achievements
Judge their choices harshly while pretending it's for their own good
Give them honest but kind feedback that considers their feelings and situation

questions.question: How do you handle it when you're in a group and someone makes a mistake or does something embarrassing?

answers.text: Make sure everyone knows that I would never make such an obvious error
Make subtle comments and jokes at their expense while acting like I'm just being playful
Use their mistake as an opportunity to show everyone how much smarter and more competent I am
Lecture them about how they could have avoided the mistake if they'd been more careful or thoughtful
Help them save face and move on without making it worse for them

questions.question: What's your typical response when someone sets a boundary with you that you don't like?

answers.text: Explain why their boundary is illogical and how they're missing important information
Agree to respect it but then find sneaky ways to get around it
Make them feel guilty for having needs that inconvenience me
Keep pushing and testing the boundary until they get tired of enforcing it
Respect their boundary even if I don't understand or agree with it

questions.question: How do you typically act when you want attention but nobody is paying attention to you?

answers.text: Start explaining something complex or controversial to force people to engage with me
Act sulky and withdrawn until someone notices and asks what's wrong
Interrupt conversations and make them about me and my experiences
Create some kind of drama or crisis that forces everyone to focus on me
Accept that not every moment is about me and find ways to contribute to what's happening

questions.question: What's your honest approach to giving gifts or doing nice things for people?

answers.text: I give advice disguised as gifts and tell people exactly what they need to improve their lives
I do nice things but make sure everyone knows about it and how thoughtful I am
I keep track of what I give and expect equal or better treatment in return
I give gifts with strings attached and use them to make people feel obligated to me
I give because I genuinely want to make people happy, not because I expect something back

questions.question: How do you typically behave when you're in a romantic relationship and things aren't going your way?

answers.text: Explain to my partner why they're wrong and how they should think and feel instead
Give them the silent treatment or act cold until they figure out what they did wrong
Make everything about my needs and how they're not meeting them properly
Use emotional manipulation and guilt trips to get them to do what I want
Actually communicate my feelings and try to work together to solve problems

questions.question: What's your approach when you have to apologize for something you did wrong?

answers.text: Explain why what I did actually made sense and educate them about my reasoning
Give a half-hearted apology but make it clear that I think they're overreacting
Apologize but immediately make it about how bad I feel and how hard this is for me
Turn it around and bring up things they've done wrong to deflect from my behavior
Take full responsibility, genuinely apologize, and focus on making things right

questions.question: How do you handle it when someone cancels plans with you at the last minute?

answers.text: Lecture them about proper planning and time management skills they clearly lack
Say it's fine but then give them the cold shoulder and make passive-aggressive comments for weeks
Make them feel terrible by explaining how much this inconveniences me and ruins my entire day
Cancel on them multiple times in the future as payback and make sure they know why
Be disappointed but understand that things come up and reschedule without drama

questions.question: What's your typical response when someone doesn't respond to your texts or messages quickly enough?

answers.text: Send multiple follow-up messages explaining why immediate responses are important for communication
Start with increasingly passive-aggressive messages until they feel guilty for not responding
Take it personally and assume they're ignoring me because I'm obviously more important than whatever they're doing
Keep texting until they respond, because clearly they just didn't see my messages
Accept that people have lives and will respond when they can

know_it_all.title: Insufferable Know-It-All
know_it_all.description: You're the human equivalent of a Wikipedia article that nobody asked for. You can't let anyone have a conversation without correcting them, lecturing them, or showing off how much smarter you think you are.
know_it_all.extended:
Your particular brand of assholery is rooted in intellectual insecurity disguised as superiority. You can't simply let people be wrong about things because their ignorance somehow threatens your carefully constructed image as the smartest person in the room. You've confused having strong opinions with having wisdom, and having information with having intelligence.

The brutal reality is that you're not as smart as you think you are, and everyone can tell. Your constant need to correct and educate others isn't helping anyone - it's just satisfying your own ego at everyone else's expense. People don't come to you for knowledge; they avoid you because being around you feels like being trapped in a lecture they didn't sign up for.

You probably think you're being helpful when you mansplain things to people who already know what they're talking about, or when you interrupt conversations to provide 'context' that nobody needed. But really, you're just being a condescending prick who can't stand not being the center of intellectual attention.

Here's your reality check: being knowledgeable is great, but being insufferable about it makes all that knowledge worthless. Learn to listen, admit when you don't know something, and let other people have their moments without turning everything into a teaching opportunity.

passive_aggressive.title: Passive-Aggressive Mastermind
passive_aggressive.description: You're the kind of asshole who would rather drop hints, make people guess what's wrong, and punish them for not being mind readers than just communicate like a normal human being.
passive_aggressive.extended:
Your asshole strategy is death by a thousand cuts - never one big confrontation, just endless small acts of subtle hostility that slowly drive everyone insane. You say 'fine' when you mean 'I hate you,' agree to things you have no intention of doing well, and make people feel crazy for being upset about behavior you pretend is innocent.

The brutal truth is that you're a coward who's too scared of conflict to address problems directly, so you create elaborate schemes of indirect revenge instead. You'd rather make everyone miserable than risk having an honest conversation about what's bothering you. You've turned emotional communication into a sadistic guessing game where everyone loses except you.

You probably think you're being clever by never saying what you really mean, but really you're just being manipulative and exhausting. People don't appreciate your 'subtle' approach - they're just too tired to call you out on your bullshit.

Reality check: passive-aggression isn't a communication style, it's emotional terrorism. Learn to use your words like an adult and stop punishing people for not being psychic.

narcissistic.title: Classic Narcissistic Dickhead
narcissistic.description: You're that special type of asshole who genuinely believes the world revolves around you and can't understand why everyone else doesn't see how obviously amazing you are.
narcissistic.extended:
Your assholery is pure, uncut narcissism - you literally cannot see other people as anything more than supporting characters in the movie of your life. You lack empathy not because you're evil, but because you're so self-absorbed that other people's experiences don't register as real to you. Everything is about you, even when it's clearly not about you.

The brutal reality is that you're not nearly as special as you think you are, and your constant need for admiration is exhausting everyone around you. You don't have friends - you have an audience that you've trapped through social obligation. People don't stick around because they enjoy your company; they stick around because leaving requires more energy than tolerating your bullshit.

You probably think people are jealous of your confidence and success, but really they're just tired of being treated like props in your personal drama. Your 'confidence' is actually just selfishness with better PR.

Wake-up call: you're not the main character in everyone else's story, and your worth doesn't depend on being better than everyone around you.

control_freak.title: Micromanaging Control Freak
control_freak.description: You're the kind of asshole who can't let anyone do anything without your input, supervision, or 'improvement.' You've appointed yourself as the manager of everyone else's choices.
control_freak.extended:
Your asshole superpower is taking the joy out of everything by turning every activity into a project that needs your management. You can't let people make their own mistakes or learn their own lessons because you're convinced that your way is always the best way. You've confused being helpful with being controlling.

The brutal truth is that your need to control everything comes from your own anxiety and insecurity, but you're making it everyone else's problem. You don't trust other people to make good decisions because you don't trust yourself to handle the consequences if they make bad ones.

You probably think you're being responsible and caring when you tell people how to live their lives, but really you're just being an overbearing asshole who can't mind your own business.

Reality check: other people's lives are not your responsibility to manage, and your anxiety about things going wrong doesn't give you the right to control everything.

selfish_prick.title: Garden-Variety Selfish Prick
selfish_prick.description: You're the classic asshole who puts yourself first in every situation and can't understand why people get upset about it. Your empathy levels are in the negative numbers.
selfish_prick.extended:
Your asshole approach is refreshingly straightforward - you simply don't give a shit about anyone but yourself. You take the last slice of pizza, cancel plans when something better comes up, and expect people to be grateful for whatever scraps of attention you throw their way.

The brutal reality is that your selfishness isn't strength or independence - it's just being a shitty person who takes more than they give. You might get what you want in the short term, but you're burning through relationships faster than you can build them.

You probably justify your behavior by claiming that 'everyone does it' or that 'nice guys finish last,' but really you're just too lazy and entitled to consider how your actions affect other people.

Wake-up call: being selfish all the time isn't sustainable, and eventually you'll run out of people willing to put up with your shit.

emotional_manipulator.title: Emotional Manipulator Supreme
emotional_manipulator.description: You're the kind of asshole who has weaponized emotions and turned every interaction into a psychological chess game where you always win.
emotional_manipulator.extended:
Your particular brand of assholery is insidious because you've figured out how to make people feel bad for not giving you what you want. You use guilt, fear, obligation, and sympathy as tools to control others, and you're so good at it that your victims often don't realize they're being manipulated until it's too late.

The brutal truth is that you're not clever or strategic - you're just a predator who feeds on other people's kindness and empathy. You don't build genuine relationships; you create hostage situations where people feel too guilty or afraid to leave.

You probably think you're just being persuasive or that you're teaching people to care about your needs, but really you're just being an abusive asshole who can't get what they want through honest means.

Reality check: manipulation isn't a relationship skill, it's emotional abuse. Learn to ask for what you need directly and accept 'no' as an answer.

toxic_competitor.title: Toxic Competitor
toxic_competitor.description: You're the kind of asshole who can't let anyone have a moment without turning it into a competition where you need to come out on top.
toxic_competitor.extended:
Your asshole specialty is sucking the joy out of other people's success by making everything about winning and losing. You can't celebrate someone else's promotion without mentioning your bigger salary, can't listen to someone's vacation story without talking about your better trip.

The brutal reality is that your need to win every interaction comes from deep insecurity about your own worth. You've tied your self-esteem to being better than others instead of being good at things for their own sake.

You probably think your competitive spirit is motivating and inspiring, but really it's just exhausting and obnoxious. People don't want to be in constant competition with their friends.

Wake-up call: life isn't a zero-sum game where someone else's success takes away from yours.

judgmental_critic.title: Professional Judgmental Critic
judgmental_critic.description: You're the kind of asshole who can't see anything without immediately identifying what's wrong with it. You're a walking criticism machine.
judgmental_critic.extended:
Your asshole superpower is being able to find the worst in every situation, person, and idea. You've convinced yourself that being critical makes you sophisticated and discerning, but really you're just a pessimistic buzzkill who sucks the life out of every room you enter.

The brutal truth is that your constant criticism isn't helping anyone improve - it's just satisfying your need to feel superior by tearing other things down. You don't build anything positive; you just destroy other people's enthusiasm and confidence.

You probably think you're being helpful by pointing out all the problems you see, but really you're just being a miserable asshole who can't let people enjoy things.

Reality check: being able to find fault in everything doesn't make you smart or sophisticated - it makes you a negative person that people avoid.

attention_whore.title: Shameless Attention Whore
attention_whore.description: You're the kind of asshole who needs to be the center of attention at all times and will do whatever it takes to redirect focus back to yourself.
attention_whore.extended:
Your asshole method is emotional terrorism through neediness - you demand constant attention and validation, and you make everyone uncomfortable when you don't get it. You interrupt stories to tell your own, hijack conversations to make them about you, and create drama when people aren't paying you enough attention.

The brutal reality is that your desperate need for attention comes from a deep insecurity, but you're making it everyone else's problem to fix. You don't want genuine connection - you want an audience. You exhaust people with your constant need for validation.

You probably think you're just being social and engaging, but really you're being a self-centered asshole who can't let anyone else have a moment.

Wake-up call: constantly demanding attention doesn't make you interesting - it makes you needy and exhausting.

boundary_stomper.title: Boundary-Stomping Bulldozer
boundary_stomper.description: You're the kind of asshole who thinks other people's boundaries are just suggestions that don't apply to you. You're basically a human boundary violation.
boundary_stomper.extended:
Your asshole specialty is making people uncomfortable and then acting like they're being unreasonable for having limits. You show up uninvited, ask inappropriate questions, give unwanted advice, and generally treat other people's personal space like public property.

The brutal truth is that you don't respect boundaries because you don't respect the people who set them. You think your intentions matter more than their comfort, and you use 'just trying to help' as an excuse to bulldoze through every limit people set.

You probably think you're being friendly and involved when you ignore people's clearly stated limits, but really you're just being an asshole who can't take no for an answer.

Reality check: other people's boundaries aren't negotiable, and your good intentions don't give you the right to ignore them.

fake_nice.title: Fake Nice Manipulator
fake_nice.description: You're the kind of asshole who hides behind a mask of niceness while being secretly judgmental, manipulative, and mean. Your kindness comes with conditions.
fake_nice.extended:
Your asshole strategy is being two-faced - presenting yourself as caring and supportive while actually being judgmental and manipulative. You master the art of backhanded compliments, passive-aggressive 'help,' and conditional kindness.

The brutal truth is that your fake niceness is more harmful than honest assholery because at least honest assholes let people know where they stand. You create an atmosphere of distrust where people never know which version of you they're getting.

You probably think you're being diplomatic and maintaining relationships by being fake nice, but really you're just being a cowardly asshole who's too scared to be authentic.

Wake-up call: fake niceness is worse than honest rudeness because at least rude people are authentic about their assholery.

surprisingly_decent.title: Surprisingly Decent Human
surprisingly_decent.description: Holy shit, you're actually a decent person who treats others with respect and kindness. In a world full of assholes, you're that rare specimen - someone who's actually considerate.
surprisingly_decent.extended:
Your 'asshole type' is that you're not an asshole at all, which is honestly refreshing. You seem to have figured out that treating people well isn't rocket science - it just requires basic empathy and consideration. You listen more than you talk, support others without making it about yourself, and generally behave like a functional adult.

The reality is that you probably took this test expecting to discover your hidden asshole tendencies, but it turns out you're just a decent person who occasionally has bad days like everyone else. Your worst traits are probably just normal human flaws that don't rise to the level of true assholery.

You might sometimes feel like you're surrounded by assholes and wonder if you're missing something, but really you're just seeing clearly. Your decency isn't naivety - it's emotional intelligence and basic human kindness.

Keep being yourself because the world needs more people like you. Your kindness and consideration aren't weaknesses - they're strengths that make you someone people actually want to be around.
